objtitle.title: *Lower Half of a Woman Playing a Harp*

objdescid.compdate: c. 1785This drawing is dated to c. 1780 in Butlin 77 verso, but revised to c. 1785 in Martin Butlin, *William Blake 1757-1827*, Tate Gallery Collections: Volume Five (London: Tate Gallery, 1990) 55-56.

objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe pencil letters and numbers and the inscription in red, both lower right, are not by Blake. The pencil inscription relates to the Tate Collection acquisition number.

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; Tatham's brother-in-law, George Richmond; sold from Richmond's collection, Christie's, 29 April 1897, lot 147 with 21 other works, most by Blake and his brother Robert (£2.10s. to Richard Sisley); Sisley's daughter, Mrs. John Richmond, probably by gift or inheritance; given by Mrs. Richmond to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection) in 1922.

desc.objtitle: Lower Half of a Woman Playing a Harp, object 1 (Butlin 77 verso)

objnote.p: Brown stains cover much of this leaf. This design is the lower half of a drawing. For the upper half, see *Woman Playing a Harp*, Butlin 76 verso. For the sketch on the recto of this leaf, see *Seraphim and Other Drawings*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure visible from the waist down is depicted in this drawing. The figure is seated with knees turned to the left. It is unclear whether the chair on which she sits is visible next to her hips at right or if this material is part of the gown's drapery. Two vertical lines appear near the left edge of the design, and two right hands, one above the other, are shown behind these lines with palms facing forward, fingers pointing left, though with different gestures. This drawing is the bottom half of a drawing, *Woman Playing a Harp*, Butlin 76 verso, that shows the upper half of a seated girl playing the harp, indicating the figure in this drawing is likely female. The sketched hands at left may be alternative ideas for the girl's right hand plucking the harp-strings shown in the upper half of the related drawing.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure visible from the waist down is depicted in this drawing. The figure is seated with knees turned to the left. This drawing is the bottom half of a related drawing, Woman Playing a Harp*, Butlin 76 verso, that shows the upper half of a seated girl playing the harp, indicating the figure in this drawing is likely female.
It is unclear whether the chair on which the figure sits is visible next to her hips at right or if this material is part of the gown's drapery.

Two right hands, one above the other, are shown behind two vertical lines near the left edge of the design. The palms face forward with fingers pointing left, but with different gestures. The index finger of the upper hand is bent toward the palm whereas all fingers of the lower hand appear to be extended and spread. Because a girl is shown playing a harp in the related upper half of this work (*Woman Playing a Harp*, Butlin 76 verso), the sketched hands may be alternative ideas for the girl's right hand plucking the harp-strings.
The two vertical lines visible near the left edge of the design may represent strings of a harp that the figure plays in the related upper half of this work *Woman Playing a Harp*, Butlin 76 verso).
